messages.subject: Re: common or no ?
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Rich I was interested to read your comments re shumei attributions on tsuba, and agree that they appear to be very rare.  I made reference to one such,
messages.messageBody:
Dear Rich

I was interested to read your comments re shumei attributions on
tsuba, and agree that they appear to be very rare. I made reference
to one such, rather enigmatic inscription on an iron, katchushi
tsuba in message #2794, and have copied the illustrations again in
my JPL photo album.

It would be interesting to see photographs of any such examples that
other members may have.

Regards, John L.


--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Richard Turner <ikkanshi@...>
wrote:
>
> All, I am wondering how common, if at all Shumei ( red lacquer )
> attribution on Tsuba are. I assume not too common ?. If they were
done,
> who would have done them ?, was anyone known to have done this ?.
>
> Cheers
>
> Rich
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>

messages.subject: common or no ?
messages.msgSnippet: All, I am wondering how common, if at all Shumei ( red lacquer ) attribution on Tsuba are. I assume not too common ?. If they were done, who would have done
messages.messageBody:
All, I am wondering how common, if at all Shumei ( red lacquer )
attribution on Tsuba are. I assume not too common ?. If they were done,
who would have done them ?, was anyone known to have done this ?.

Cheers

Rich

messages.msgSnippet: Rich, all - Is Mr. Shibata--I forget his first name--still alive and running the business today? I believe he was here with John Yumoto for the long-ago
messages.messageBody:
Rich, all -

Is Mr. Shibata--I forget his first name--still alive and running the business today? I believe he was here with John Yumoto for the long-ago Albuquerque shinsa. Never met him but did correspond with him years ago. Nice, helpful fellow. Just curious.

Ron
STL

From: alchemyst
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, April 21, 2004 8:23 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba Taikan


I've dealt with Koshoyama books several times and found them
to be very helpful, reliable and inexpensive relative to other
book dealers.

You might also try Sibata. His website is in Japanese only,
but he reads/speaks English and will answer inquiries about
books, etc. on his site. Also reasonable prices and shipping IMHO>

http://www.tokensibata.co.jp/

Rich S

to be very helpful, reliable and inexpensive relative to other

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba Taikan
messages.msgSnippet: Ron and all, When I looked up the url for Koshoyama for you I noticed that they re selling Ikeda and Miyake s Ko-Kogai for only US$180.  The Tosogu museum
messages.messageBody:
Ron and all,
When I looked up the url for Koshoyama for you I noticed that they're selling Ikeda and Miyake's "Ko-Kogai" for only US$180. The Tosogu museum used to sell this for around $600. I don't know if it's a single used copy or if Koshoyama bought the unsold inventory. Either way it's a good price if you're interested in Ko-Goto, Ko-Kinko and Ko-Mino work. Around 500 kogai organized according to motif, illustrated in large color photos.
Jim



Hi Paul -

Not sure which Paul...but my private reply to you (kidjapan2003) keeps bouncing back to me as undeliverable. Believe you are on this group, so I'll try to reach you here. The question was with regards to ordering Tsuba Taikan reprint, so maybe others might also like to read this. Just ordered a copy from Koshoyama (Japan) at $300 plus $54 EMS shipping (fastest) and paid by International Postal Money Order (requiring no bank fees in Japan).

Ron
STL
